update.description:
By default, the space navigator will control the user camera.

Functionality can be changed in ~/.gazebo/gui.ini, with


```
#!c++

[spacenav]
deadband_x = 0.1
deadband_y = 0.1
deadband_z = 0.1
deadband_rx = 0.1
deadband_ry = 0.1
deadband_rz = 0.1
topic=~/spacenav/joy
```

Requires:

```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install libspnav-dev
```
update.title: Integrated space navigator joystick

content.raw: As far as I know the cost of a scoped_ptr is minimal (the overhead is different compared with a shared_ptr). I agree that we don't need to share the pointer with anyone and that's why scoped_ptr is good because you cannot do it :) . In any case not a big deal, I'll leave it to you.
content.html: As far as I know the cost of a scoped_ptr is minimal (the overhead is different compared with a shared_ptr). I agree that we don't need to share the pointer with anyone and that's why scoped_ptr is good because you cannot do it :) . In any case not a big deal, I'll leave it to you.

content.raw: This did get fixed, forget to reply to this comment.
content.html: This did get fixed, forget to reply to this comment.

content.raw: Same as my previous response. The spacenav is a private pointer that is not shared. We can manage the pointer with the destructor.
content.html: Same as my previous response. The spacenav is a private pointer that is not shared. We can manage the pointer with the destructor.

content.raw: I don't like to introduce unneeded overhead. We don't use shared pointers for private data structures. They are not shared with anyone, and we can manage the memory with the destructor.
content.html: I don't like to introduce unneeded overhead. We don't use shared pointers for private data structures. They are not shared with anyone, and we can manage the memory with the destructor.

content.raw: Consider to change the raw pointer to a boost::scoped_ptr
content.html: Consider to change the raw pointer to a boost::scoped_ptr

content.raw: Consider to change the raw pointer to a boost::scoped_ptr and remove the code from the destructor.
content.html: Consider to change the raw pointer to a boost::scoped_ptr and remove the code from the destructor.

content.raw: This returns true when the space navigator is opened or when the space navigatory library is not installed. False otherwise.
content.html: This returns true when the space navigator is opened or when the space navigatory library is not installed. False otherwise.

content.raw: incomplete ... "or" -> "or False ..."
content.html: incomplete ... "or" -> "or False ..."

content.raw: This is feature creep for a device that we do not have. Once we have a use case with something to test against, then we can make appropriate additions or deletions.
content.html: This is feature creep for a device that we do not have. Once we have a use case with something to test against, then we can make appropriate additions or deletions.

content.raw:
I actually came across another use case, using a 6 dof sensor as the "joystick", where it would have been better to have Quaternion for rotation.

In other words, for relative orientation sensing (as in this case with Spacenav), Vector3d works well, but for 6 dof absolute orientation sensing (as with Hydra or Liberty for example), quaternion maybe be more ideal. Can/should we add an optional quaternion here in the message?
content.html:
I actually came across another use case, using a 6 dof sensor as the "joystick", where it would have been better to have Quaternion for rotation.

In other words, for relative orientation sensing (as in this case with Spacenav), Vector3d works well, but for 6 dof absolute orientation sensing (as with Hydra or Liberty for example), quaternion maybe be more ideal. Can/should we add an optional quaternion here in the message?

content.raw: Yeah, I came to the same conclusion after a discussion with Nate, but I forgot to update the comment thread. I think we're ok linking to the BSD library.
content.html: Yeah, I came to the same conclusion after a discussion with Nate, but I forgot to update the comment thread. I think we're ok linking to the BSD library.

content.raw: I won't say that any interaction with a daemon from you program count as a 'derived work' in any sense, which I believe that is the key part of the propagation of the GPL. I'm far from being an expert in this legal case though.
content.html: I won't say that any interaction with a daemon from you program count as a 'derived work' in any sense, which I believe that is the key part of the propagation of the GPL. I'm far from being an expert in this legal case though.

content.raw:
Looks good. Other parts of the MainWindow_TEST are failing, but I successfully ran the UserCameraJoystick test as follows:
~~~
pwd:gazebo/build $ gazebo/gui/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST UserCameraJoystick
********* Start testing of MainWindow_TEST *********
Config: Using QTest library 4.8.6, Qt 4.8.6
PASS   : MainWindow_TEST::initTestCase()
QWARN  : MainWindow_TEST::UserCameraJoystick() QObject::connect: Cannot connect (null)::DeleteSignal(const std::string &) to gazebo::gui::ModelCreator::OnDelete(const std::string &)
SharePercentChange[0.722512] ShareMaxPercentChange[2]
ResPercentChange[1.68862]ResMaxPercentChange[5]
PASS   : MainWindow_TEST::UserCameraJoystick()
PASS   : MainWindow_TEST::cleanupTestCase()
Totals: 3 passed, 0 failed, 0 skipped
********* Finished testing of MainWindow_TEST *********
~~~
content.html:
Looks good. Other parts of the MainWindow_TEST are failing, but I successfully ran the UserCameraJoystick test as follows:

pwd:gazebo/build $ gazebo/gui/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST UserCameraJoystick

ResPercentChange[1.68862]ResMaxPercentChange[5]

********* Finished testing of MainWindow_TEST *********

content.raw:
Repeating a comment from pull request #1166, I'd like to see documentation about this rotation vector. John said:

"it's 3 doubles, each indicating the amount of rotation along x, y and z axis, normalized between -1 and 1, so similar to fixed axis roll pitch yaw. But it's not a true orientation indicator, so I like Vector3d better here (than quaternion)."

Can we add a comment about the format of this rotation vector? Or should we leave it ambiguous?
content.html:
Repeating a comment from pull request #1166, I'd like to see documentation about this rotation vector. John said:

"it's 3 doubles, each indicating the amount of rotation along x, y and z axis, normalized between -1 and 1, so similar to fixed axis roll pitch yaw. But it's not a true orientation indicator, so I like Vector3d better here (than quaternion)."

Can we add a comment about the format of this rotation vector? Or should we leave it ambiguous?

content.raw: Only rotations about x are disabled.
content.html: Only rotations about x are disabled.

content.raw:
Actually it appears that spacenavd is required:
~~~
[Err] [SpaceNav.cc:80] Unable to open space navigator device.Please make sure you have run spacenavd as root.
~~~
I don't know how GPL works. If we link with `libspnav` (BSD) and it interacts with the system daemon `spacenavd` (GPL), does the GPL propagate?
content.html:
Actually it appears that spacenavd is required:

[Err] [SpaceNav.cc:80] Unable to open space navigator device.Please make sure you have run spacenavd as root.

I don't know how GPL works. If we link with libspnav (BSD) and it interacts with the system daemon spacenavd (GPL), does the GPL propagate?

content.raw:
Note: the [libspnav library is licensed BSD](http://spacenav.sourceforge.net), but the spacenavd daemon is licensed GPL3. We're fine since we're only using libspnav; we should be careful not to use spacenavd.

Also, this library [does not work on Mac](http://sourceforge.net/p/spacenav/mailman/message/29266348/). Mac users would need to download the proprietary drivers from the manufacturer.
content.html:
Note: the libspnav library is licensed BSD, but the spacenavd daemon is licensed GPL3. We're fine since we're only using libspnav; we should be careful not to use spacenavd.

Also, this library does not work on Mac. Mac users would need to download the proprietary drivers from the manufacturer.
